column4: Hi everyone, does anyone know how to forward packets for UPnP?  I have a desktop with mediatomb connected by CAT5 to a laptop that connects to my router via wireless.  If I connect the desktop by wireless to my router i can reach everything on mediatomb from my PS3 (via wireless to the router).  With this configuration though the laptop is the gateway for the desktop.  so router is 192.168.1.1, laptop connected to router at 192.168.1.6, lap
Have you looked in network manager's settings? I found it very easy to 'bridge' last time I looked.
(netowrk manager is the little icon next to the clock)
Well, it is essentially a bridge, is it not?  And I'm not sure how well network manager will play with the changes I've made, could just end up with a mess couldn't I?
Separate network cards requires 'effort' to bridge.
Unless I've mistaken.
I think I did my original setup that way some months ago just for forwarding to one comp, but I think for UPnP I need something a bit different
By the way, your message was cut off at 'connected to router' so I had to guess at your problem ;)

here's the rest  at 192.168.1.6, laptop acts as gateway (10.42.43.1) for desktop (10.42.43.53), I've managed to forward my tcp traffic with iptables on the laptop and can ping back and forth from the desktop to the rest of the network and vice versa.  So I think I just need a rule or two for iptables to get the UPnP working.    (didn't show the cut off on mine for some reason)
Is there any reason why you want to do it with random iptables?
I'd far and away reccomend getting rid of what you've done and using network-manager instead. It'll bridge the two. No messy NAT's.
As far as the other machine will be concerned, it'll be on the real network.
just that I don't think the network manager method was working out for me, I'm willing to try again though, I'm all ears ^_^
I'm not on an ubuntu machine atm so I'm little use... but i know that it was easy peasy when i did it.
So if I go into the network manager and to edit connection for my wired connection (to the desktop), under ipv4 settings, the method is set as "Shared to other computers"
i think that sounds right

Yeah, that seems to work great for just internet, but laptop keeps it's own ip for the connection, and the desktop gets it's ip from the laptop, not the router.  So I had to add a route to the router in order to ping back and forth, so now I thought all traffic should be going where it should, but the UPnP just doesn't seem to be working, so I was resorting to iptables because I think I needed to convince the laptop to send all traf
that was the wrong option then... is there another one? 'bridge interfaces' or similar?
they are, Automatic (DHCP), Automatic (DHCP) addresses only, Manual, Link-Local Only, Shared to other computers, and Disabled
Maybe I'm just imagining it :-/ I've got to head off now. Check out https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BridgingNetworkInterfaces I still think you'd have better luck bridging than the other way.
thanks for the help though, I remember seeing something like what you're saying in the past, don't see it here now though
